seo.defaultDescription: Quantix: A high-performance CPU scheduling visualizer supporting 11 algorithms, multi-core simulation, and detailed analytics.

home.title: Quantix | CPU Scheduling Visualizer
home.description: Visualize and compare 11 CPU scheduling algorithms with multi-core support, energy modeling, and real-time Gantt charts.

playground.title: Playground | Quantix CPU Visualizer
playground.description: Experiment with FCFS, SJF, RR, MLFQ and more. Adjust core counts, context switch overhead, and energy parameters in real-time.

compare.title: Compare Algorithms | Quantix
compare.description: Batch run CPU scheduling algorithms to compare average wait times, turnaround times, and energy efficiency.

guide.title: Algorithm Guide | Quantix
guide.description: Learn the theory behind CPU scheduling: FCFS, Round Robin, Multi-level Feedback Queues, and more.

about.title: About Quantix
about.description: The mission and technology behind Quantix CPU Scheduling Visualizer.

welcome.title: Welcome to Quantix
welcome.desc: This interactive tutorial will guide you through the core concepts of CPU scheduling algorithms. Learn how processes are managed, executed, and prioritized by the operating system.

processes.title: Processes & The Ready Queue
processes.desc: A process is a program in execution. In our visualizer, processes waiting for CPU time are placed in the "Ready Queue". Algorithms decide WHICH process from this queue runs next.

gantt.title: The Gantt Chart
gantt.desc: The timeline below is a Gantt Chart. It visualizes the execution order. Blocks represent time slices given to processes. "CS" blocks represent Context Switching overhead.

fcfs.title: First-Come, First-Served (FCFS)
fcfs.desc: The simplest algorithm. Processes are executed in the exact order they arrive. Great for simplicity, but can lead to the "Convoy Effect" where short processes wait behind long ones.

rr.title: Round Robin (RR)
rr.desc: Designed for fair sharing. Each process gets a fixed "Time Quantum" (e.g., 2ms). If it doesn't finish, it moves to the back of the queue. Try adjusting the Quantum slider!

sjf.title: Shortest Job First (SJF)
sjf.desc: Optimizes for minimum waiting time. The process with the shortest burst time runs first. However, long processes may starve if short ones keep arriving.

step.title: Step-by-Step Execution
step.desc: Use the "Step Forward" button to see exactly why an algorithm made a decision. The "Decision Log" panel will explain the logic (e.g., "Selected P1 because priority is highest").

load.title: Load Scenario
load.confirmDelete: Are you sure you want to delete "{{name}}"?
